name: sfchronicle
text: A McDonald’s employee in Oakland said she was grabbed, hit and slapped by a drive-through customer after she told him he had to wear a face mask in order to receive his order. https://t.co/MR9FnQTqe9

name: sfchronicle
text:
For those who make their living covering baseball, a grim new era begins on Friday. 

@Bruce_Jenkins1's column: https://t.co/xLVEUDRXdm

name: sfchronicle
text: Some older Oakland A’s staff members are adjusting their jobs to account for their at-risk status, and team doctor Allen Pont will work remotely during the coronavirus pandemic, he told @susanslusser. https://t.co/ENaazA7o92

name: sfchronicle
text:
The coronavirus isn’t stopping new Bay Area restaurants from opening — even though they can only operate with takeout and delivery.

Here is a running list of what has opened since the Bay Area’s shelter-in-place orders began on March 17.

https://t.co/LRFVTR2mKM

name: sfchronicle
text:
Shut up and dribble? Or work for change? Athletes have power, and no one can stop them from using it, writes @AnnKillion.

https://t.co/L8u13TH7jk

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @SportingGreenSF: Sports digest: Sponsor FedEx asks Washington's NFL team to change its nickname; Oakland native Tyson Ross, a free agent recently released by Giants, will join brother Joe in sitting out the MLB season due to coronavirus concerns. https://t.co/VkrUasAOJQ

name: sfchronicle
text: A federal judge ordered state prison officials Thursday to transfer two mentally ill inmates who said they were assaulted by guards after speaking with lawyers who were looking into the death of another inmate. https://t.co/HYc7eLxKoX

name: sfchronicle
text: San Francisco, which once packed 68 crowded bus lines into its tight streets, stands to lose most of them as the pandemic sinks its transit budget and steers riders into cars. https://t.co/u22n54w4mG

name: sfchronicle
text: Muni will lose the majority of its bus lines permanently as pandemic sinks S.F. transit budget and steers more riders into cars. https://t.co/Mey02unFh8

name: sfchronicle
text:
“The cuts that we’re making are terribly painful.”

Just about every aspect of San Francisco’s transportation future looks grim. https://t.co/dr5Cnjm7Jc

name: sfchronicle
text: Californians will see a lengthy list of initiatives and referendums on their November ballot, from funding for stem-cell research to a repeal of the state’s ban on affirmative action. https://t.co/DfMAGAOCzd

name: sfchronicle
text:
During the pandemic, @makamham has been dreaming up a boxed version of their essential pop-up, Cafe Ohlone, filled with gathered black sage, honey-scented manzanita blossoms and other culinary components.

https://t.co/q0Q72xxd8I

name: sfchronicle
text: Looking for a Fourth of July weekend getaway? The best opportunities are off-the grid campsites, first-come, first-served, at lakes in remote national forests, and @StienstraTom some ideas: https://t.co/rxhHyaFGdl

name: sfchronicle
text: ICYMI: Up to 40 of the bus lines that SF cut at the beginning of the pandemic are not coming back unless the city finds a new revenue spigot, transportation chief Jeffrey Tumlin said this week. https://t.co/SXD03hdw2D
